这个传闻已经传了很多年了，但任天堂仍然在晚些时候发布了一个令我们惊讶的消息：一部基于《塞尔达传说》的真人电影正在制作中，由韦斯·鲍尔执导。鲍尔最近的电影是《移动迷宫》系列，最新一部于 2018 年上映。任天堂的宫本茂与阿维·阿拉德一起制作了这部电影，阿维·阿拉德在过去十多年里制作或监制了很多漫威电影。

令人惊讶的是，这部电影是由任天堂和索尼影视娱乐公司共同资助的。你知道，它隶属于拥有 PlayStation 的同一家公司。任天堂很快指出，它为这部电影提供了超过 50% 的资金，但索尼影视娱乐公司将成为影院发行商。

除此之外，除了宫本茂的这条推文之外，没有其他细节：

这是宫本。我多年来一直与阿维·阿拉德桑一起制作《塞尔达传说》的真人电影，他制作了许多热门电影。 [1]

— 任天堂株式会社 (@Nintendo) 2023 年 11 月 7 日

宫本接着说，他们已经正式开始这部电影的开发，任天堂“大力参与”制作。他还指出，完成之前“需要时间”，但他希望粉丝们期待看到它。

早在 2015 年， 我们就从《华尔街日报》听到传言称任天堂和 Netflix 正在制作真人版塞尔达传说，但最终没有实现（关于原因有一个非常奇怪的故事）。但《超级马里奥兄弟电影》的成功也许是任天堂让这个项目成为现实所需要的最后一件事。虽然从现在到电影上映之间有很多时间会出现问题，但这位塞尔达迷对另一部经典任天堂系列电影登上大银幕的前景感到谨慎兴奋。

如果您的 Apple Watch 无法像以前一样保持电量，那么是时候更新到最新版本的 watchOS 了。本月早些时候，一些 Apple Watch 用户注意到在安装 watchOS 10.1 后，他们的电池消耗速度比平时更快。当然，用户在社交媒体上表达了他们的观察结果，并确保这不是一个孤立的事件。后来， 苹果公司承认了电池消耗问题，并承诺发布修复程序——今天最新版本的 watchOS 就出现了这一问题。 10.1.1。具体来说，苹果公司表示，此次更新“解决了可能导致某些用户电池更快耗尽的问题”。

多年来，苹果公司在软件更新方面取得了长足的进步。如今，苹果的大部分更新都相当稳定，但这并不意味着它们不会受到偶尔会严重影响用户的错误的影响。 Apple Watch 是一款可穿戴设备，已融入许多人的日常生活。为了满足用户的需求，智能手表良好的电池续航时间至关重要。

因此，由于电池耗尽问题已经影响了相当多的用户，所以这个修复不可能很快到来。一位用户表示“watchOS 10.1 正在耗尽我 Apple Watch 的电池”，导致其电量在不到一小时内从 100% 下降到 50%。此外，该问题还全面影响了 Apple Watch，包括 SE 等较旧型号和Apple Watch Ultra 2等最新型号。

像往常一样，Apple 的 watchOS 10.1.1 还包括未指定的错误修复。与往常一样，此更新与相应的 iOS 更新 17.1.1 一起发布。此更新解决了 Apple Pay 和 NFC 功能在某些车辆中进行无线充电后在 iPhone 15 型号上停止工作的问题。它还对锁定屏幕上天气小部件上的下雪图形进行了非常重要的修复。

据报道，代表好莱坞演员的工会 SAG-AFTRA 已对制片厂提出的结束罢工的“最后、最好和最终”提议作出回应，拒绝了允许他们在不使用人工智能创建的高需求和已故演员肖像的条款。同意。据称，该工会计划提出还价，删除当前与人工智能相关的语言。 “他们不能利用这个漏洞来剥削表演者，”工会方面的消息人士周一告诉《好莱坞报道》 。 “我们不能允许这种语言继续存在。”

据《THR》报道，电影和电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 提议对 Schedule F 表演者（联盟成员每集收入超过 32,000 美元或每部电影收入超过 60,000 美元）进行“安全人工智能扫描”。电影公司建议的交易将要求他们支付一次费用来扫描 Schedule F 表演者的肖像，而无需支付使用或重复使用的费用——本质上是在预付一次费用后给予他们对其肖像的永久权利。

一个更引人注目的细节是，该提案的撰写方式似乎主张在未经适当许可的情况下无限制地使用已故表演者的人工智能创建的肖像。 THR写道：“目前 AMPTP 的提议中的措辞是，工作室和流媒体将获得使用已故表演者扫描图像的权利，而无需获得其遗产委员会或美国演员工会联合会 (SAG-AFTRA) 的同意。”据报道，SAG-AFTRA 希望每次工作室或流媒体重复使用表演者的人工智能扫描时都附上同意要求和补偿。然而，在这部分争议公开后， 《综艺》 报道称，工会与 AMPTP 就演员死亡后人工智能同意等“棘手问题”“达成了共识”。

“我们认为这不仅合理，而且对演出行业的可持续发展绝对至关重要，”一位消息人士在修改报价的消息传出之前告诉《好莱坞报道》 。 “[AMPTP 提案中的 Schedule F AI 语言]他们理应让你死去，因为他们在你活着时需要征得同意，但在你死后则不需要。”

据报道，SAG-AFTRA 周一向工会成员通报了谈判情况，向他们保证不会同意一份糟糕的合同。该工会在给其成员的信中写道：“请知道，我们电视/戏剧谈判委员会的每一位成员都决心达成正确的协议，从而负责任地结束这次罢工。” “我们在几个重要项目上仍未达成一致，包括人工智能。随着事件的进展，我们将随时向您通报情况。”

科技行业正受到经济不景气、新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 大流行和一些明显的商业失误的影响。虽然这导致了 2022 年的裁员，但不幸的是，2023 年的裁员人数有所增加。跟踪这些举措可能很困难，因此我们将所有重大裁员汇总在一处，并将继续更新此故事随着局势的发展。

十一月

育碧蒙特利尔裁员

11 月初，育碧在蒙特利尔办事处解雇了 98 名员工，该办事处被认为是该公司最大的内部开发团队的所在地。大多数失业者从事的是工商管理和 IT 行业。总体而言，该公司在最新的季度收益报告中表示，过去12个月已裁员约1,000人，包括裁员和不替换自愿离职的员工。

十月

领英裁员

LinkedIn 表示，在今年的第二轮裁员中，该公司将裁掉来自工程、产品、人才和财务团队的约 668 名员工。 5 月，LinkedIn 表示将裁员 716 人，并关闭其在中国的求职应用程序。在两轮裁员之间，LinkedIn 将在 2023 年裁员近 1,400 人。

九月

Epic Games 裁员

Epic Games 解雇了 16%的员工，即约 830 名员工。首席执行官蒂姆·斯威尼(Tim Sweeney)在一封致员工的公开信中表示，公司花的钱比赚的钱“多得多”，“我们的结论是裁员是唯一的办法”。此前，该公司曾试图通过冻结招聘和削减营销支出来降低成本。

Roku裁员

Roku 2023 年第二轮裁员将导致另外 300 名员工离开公司，除了3 月份解雇的200 名员工以及 2022 年末解雇的另外 200 名员工之外。Roku 再次寻求降低成本，并在减少员工人数的同时，它正试图通过从其平台上删除节目和电影、整合办公空间并减少外部服务支出来做到这一点。

七月

谷歌裁员

谷歌在 7 月份引起了人们的关注，当时其合同合作伙伴埃森哲解雇了80 名帮助分包商，这些分包商在前一个月投票成立了 Alphabet 工人联盟 (CWA)。埃森哲将此举归因于削减成本。尽管该公司表示尊重分包商加入工会的权利，但前团队指责谷歌对劳工组织者进行报复。

CD Projekt Red 裁员

《赛博朋克 2077》的创作者也未能幸免于商业挑战。 CD Projekt Red 在 7 月份警告称，它将在未来几个月内裁员约 100 人，约占员工总数的 9%。员工最晚将在 2024 年第一季度被解雇。首席执行官 Adam Kiciński 坦白了原因：CDPR 因重组而“人满为患”，旨在更好地处理游戏开发商不断扩大的产品路线图，其中包括新的《赛博朋克》和《巫师》游戏。

六月

Spotify 裁员

Spotify 继 1 月份的裁员计划之后，于 6 月份宣布将在其播客部门裁员 200 人。此举是更有针对性的方法的一部分，旨在为创作者和节目提供优化的资源来培育播客。该公司还将其 Gimlet 和 Parcast 制作团队合并为新的 Spotify Studios 部门。

GrubHub 裁员

GrubHub 面临着来自经济和 Uber 等竞争对手的巨大压力，这导致其在 6 月份解雇了 15% 的员工，即大约 400 名员工。就在几周前，即将卸任的首席执行官亚当·德威特 (Adam DeWitt) 正式离开食品配送服务行业。新任首席执行官霍华德·米格达尔 (Howard Migdal) 声称，裁员将有助于公司保持“竞争力”。

拥抱集团裁员

游戏发行巨头 Embracer Group 于 6 月宣布了裁员计划，作为旨在削减成本的重大重组工作的一部分。该公司没有透露 17,000 名员工中有多少人会受到影响，但预计检修将持续到 3 月份。消息传出后不久，Embracer 透露，尽管有口头协议，但该公司还是失去了与一位未透露姓名的合作伙伴的 20 亿美元交易。

索诺斯裁员

Sonos 最近一直在努力扭亏为盈，并且正在削减成本以重回正轨。该公司 6 月份表示将裁员 7% ，即大约 130 个工作岗位。它还计划出售房地产并重新考虑项目支出。首席执行官帕特里克·斯宾塞表示，“持续的不利因素”包括销售萎缩。

普莱克斯裁员

Plex 可能是许多用户流媒体本地和在线媒体的首选应用程序，但这并没有帮助它的命运。该公司 6 月份解雇了大约 20% 的员工，即 37 人。削减影响到所有领域。据报道，Plex 感受到了广告市场放缓的打击，并渴望削减成本并扭亏为盈。

可能

Shopify裁员

Shopify 的电子商务平台在疫情最严重的时候发挥了重要作用，但这家加拿大公司现在正在缩减规模，因为疫情高峰已经结束。 5 月份，该公司解雇了20% 的员工，并将其物流业务出售给 Flexport。创始人 Tobi Lütke 表示，裁员是为了“全神贯注”Shopify 的核心使命所必需的，并承认既然“稳定的经济繁荣时期”已经结束，公司需要提高效率。

北极星裁员

Polestar 在 5 月份推迟了其首款电动 SUV（Polestar 3）的生产，这对其员工造成了影响。沃尔沃衍生品牌 5 月份表示，由于面临制造预期下降和经济不景气的情况，将裁员 10%以降低成本。 Polestar 表示，沃尔沃需要更多时间进行软件开发和测试，这也导致了 EX90 的推迟。

SoundCloud 裁员

SoundCloud 继去年大规模裁员之后，今年 5 月又进行了更多裁员。这家流媒体音频服务公司表示，为了在 2023 年实现盈利，它将裁员 8% 。Billboard消息人士称，该公司希望在今年第四季度实现盈利。

四月

Lyft 裁员

Lyft 于 2022 年 11 月解雇了 13% 的员工，但在 4 月份采取了进一步措施。这家拼车公司表示将裁员 1,072 名员工，约占其员工总数的 26%。就在几周前，亚马逊前高管大卫·瑞舍（David Risher）更换了首席执行官洛根·格林（Logan Green），后者表示该公司需要精简业务并重新关注司机和乘客。格林此前表示，Lyft 需要增加支出才能与 Uber 竞争。

Dropbox 裁员

云存储公司也无法免受当前金融环境的影响。 4 月份，Dropbox 表示将裁员 500 名员工，约占团队人数的 16%。联合创始人德鲁·休斯顿 (Drew Houston) 将此次裁员归咎于经济不景气、业务日趋成熟以及对人工智能日益增长的兴趣的“紧迫性”。休斯顿表示，虽然该公司实现盈利，但其增长正在放缓，一些投资“不再可持续”。

行进

Roku裁员

Roku 于 2022 年底裁员 200 人，但这一计划并未完成。这家流媒体平台创建者于 2023 年 3 月又解雇了 200 名员工。和以前一样，该公司辩称需要抑制不断增长的开支，并专注于那些影响最大的项目。 Roku 一直在艰难应对经济不景气和流媒体视频热潮结束的双重打击。

Lucid汽车公司裁员

如果您认为豪华电动汽车制造商特别容易受到经济动荡的影响，那么您猜对了。 Lucid Motors 在 3 月份表示，将裁员 18% ，即约 1,300 人。该品牌仍未达到生产目标，据报道，这些削减有助于应对“不断变化的业务需求和生产力提高”。裁员也是全面的，包括高管和承包商。

Meta（Facebook）裁员

Meta 在 2022 年秋季裁员 11,000 人，但这还没有结束。 2023年3月，该公司宣布计划再裁员1万名，以进一步削减成本。第一次裁员影响了其招聘团队，但该公司在 4 月下旬缩减了技术团队，并在 5 月下旬缩减了业务部门。 Facebook 所有者希望通过减少管理层并要求一些领导者承担以前为普通员工保留的工作来简化其运营。 Meta 的员工数量可能需要一段时间才能再次增长——预计要到 2023 年底完成重组工作后才会解除招聘冻结。

二月

里维安裁员

Rivian 在 2022 年进行了裁员，但这不足以帮助这个羽翼未丰的电动汽车品牌实现盈利。 2 月份，该公司又解雇了6% 的员工，即约 840 名员工。该公司仍在努力实现盈利，而供应链问题造成的产量短缺也无济于事。首席执行官 RJ Scaringe 表示，裁员将帮助 Rivian 专注于其业务“影响最大”的方面。

变焦裁员

Zoom 是疫情高峰期远程工作文化的主要内容，因此，随着人们返回办公室，该公司削减开支也就不足为奇了。这家视频通话公司 2 月份表示将裁员约 1,300 名员工，占其员工总数的 15%。正如首席执行官埃里克·袁(Eric Yuan)所说，该公司在应对突如其来的成功时并没有“可持续地”招聘员工。据报道，裁员对于帮助度过困难的经济是必要的。管理团队提供的不仅仅是道歉。袁征将下一财年的工资削减 98%，而所有其他高管的基本工资以及 2023 财年奖金将减少 20%。

雅虎裁员

Engadget 的母公司雅虎也未能幸免于裁员。该互联网品牌在 2 月份表示，将在 2023 年裁员超过 20% ，即超过 1,600 人。其中大部分裁员（即大约 1,000 个职位）是立即进行的。不过，首席执行官吉姆·兰佐尼(Jim Lanzone)并未将裁员归咎于经济状况。相反，他将其定位为广告技术部门的重组，因为该部门放弃了一项不盈利的业务，​​转而支持一项成功的业务。实际上，雅虎正在退出与谷歌和 Meta 在广告市场的直接竞争。

戴尔裁员

大流行病的复苏和严峻的经济形势对个人电脑制造商的打击尤为严重，而戴尔所感受到的痛苦比大多数公司都要严重。在经历了残酷的第四季度（计算机出货量估计下降了 37%）之后，该公司在 2 月初解雇了 5% 的员工，即大约 6,650 名员工。戴尔表示，过去的成本削减努力还不够，据报道需要裁员和精简组织才能重回正轨。

Deliveroo裁员

送餐服务蓬勃发展，而新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 疫情让人们远离餐馆，现在人们愿意再次外出就餐，至少有些人感受到了刺痛。 Deliveroo 将解雇约 350 名员工，占其员工总数的 9%。创始人 Will Shu 表示，“重新部署”将使这个数字接近 300 人。理由很熟悉：舒表示，Deliveroo 迅速招聘员工来应对与疫情相关的“前所未有”的增长，但据报道，该公司在应对困难的经济形势时必须削减成本。

DocuSign 裁员

对于许多在线签署过文件的人来说，DocuSign 可能很熟悉，但这并没有使其免受恶劣经济环境的影响。该公司在 2 月中旬表示将裁员 10% 。虽然没有透露具体人数，但截至 2022 年初，该公司拥有 7,461 名员工。大多数失业人员在 DocuSign 的全球现场组织工作。

亚搏体育appGitLab裁员

您可能不知道 GitLab，但它的 DevOps（开发和运营）平台支撑着 NVIDIA 和 T-Mobile 等科技品牌的工作，而其客户业务的萎缩正在影响其利润。 GitLab 将解雇 7% 的员工，即大约 114 人。公司首席执行官西德·西布兰迪 (Sid Sijbrandij) 表示，经济问题意味着客户对软件投资采取“更加保守的方式”，而公司之前重新调整支出的尝试不足以应对这些挑战。

GoDaddy 裁员

GoDaddy 在疫情爆发初期就进行了裁员，当时其面向零售的社交平台裁掉了 800 多名员工。然而，今年二月，它采取了更广泛的行动。该网络服务提供商解雇了所有部门8% 的员工，即 500 多人。首席执行官阿曼·布塔尼 (Aman Bhutani) 声称，其他形式的成本削减不足以帮助公司应对“不确定”的经济形势，这反映了进一步整合 Main Street Hub 等收购的努力。

Twilio 裁员

Twilio 在 2022 年 9 月裁减了 800 多个工作岗位，但随着 2023 年开始，它进行了更大幅度的裁员。该云通信品牌在 2 月中旬解雇了 17% 的员工，即大约 1,500 人。与许多其他科技公司一样，Twillio 表示，过去的成本削减努力不足以承受严酷的环境。它还将裁员合理化，以精简组织。

谷歌（Alphabet）裁员

谷歌母公司 Alphabet 一段时间以来一直在削减成本，包括关闭 Stadia ，但该公司在 1 月底更进一步，表示将裁员 12,000 名员工。首席执行官桑达尔·皮查伊 (Sundar Pichai) 毫不掩饰其理由：Alphabet 一直在针对“不同的经济现实”进行招聘，并正在进行重组，以专注于这家互联网巨头最重要的业务。这一决定对该公司 120 区孵化器的打击尤为严重，该部门的大多数员工都失业了。 Intrinsic（机器人）和 Verily（健康）等子品牌也在大规模裁员前几天裁掉了大量员工。 Waymo 已进行两轮裁员，裁员 209 人，占员工总数的 8%。

亚马逊裁员

微软开始了公司历史上第二大裁员潮，该公司表示将在 1 月中旬至 3 月底期间裁员 10,000 人。与许多其他科技巨头一样，随着客户在大流行复苏期间缩减支出（特别是在 Windows 和设备上），该公司正在削减成本。这种裁员对一些部门来说尤其痛苦——据报道，他们摧毁了 HoloLens 和混合现实团队，而 343 Industries 则在失去数十名员工后据信正在重启 Halo 开发。 GitHub 正在裁员 10% ，即大约 300 人。

贝宝裁员

PayPal 一直是健康状况较好的大型科技公司之一，去年第三季度的业绩超出了预期。尽管如此，它也未能幸免于经济不景气的影响。这家在线支付公司于 1 月底公布了裁员 2,000 名员工的计划，占其员工总数的 7%。首席执行官丹·舒尔曼 (Dan Schulman) 声称，裁员将控制成本，并帮助 PayPal 专注于“核心战略重点”。

Salesforce 裁员

Salesforce 为 2023 年定下了基调，在新年仅四天后，该公司就警告称将裁员 8,000 名员工，约占员工总数的 10%。尽管该云软件品牌在疫情期间蓬勃发展，收入快速增长，但它承认在繁荣时期过于积极地招聘员工，在经济衰退时无法维持这一员工水平。

SAP裁员

商业软件巨头 SAP 的利润在 2022 年底大幅下降 68%，并从 2023 年开始裁员 2,800 名员工以保持业务健康发展。不过，与科技领域的一些知名企业不同的是，SAP 并没有将裁员归咎于大流行时期的过度招聘。相反，它将这一举措描述为一家仍预计 2023 年加速增长的公司的“有针对性的重组”。

Spotify 裁员

近年来，Spotify 大力投资扩大其播客帝国，但在 2023 年开始时很快就停止了这种做法。这家流媒体音乐服务公司在 1 月底表示，将裁员 6% （截至第三季度，Spotify 有 9,800 名员工），同时进行重组工作，其中包括内容主管 Dawn Ostroff 的离职。尽管 2022 年的高级订阅用户数量比以往任何时候都多，但该公司也遭受了巨大损失——首席执行官丹尼尔·埃克 (Daniel Ek) 表示，在收入无法支撑之前，他的投资“过于雄心勃勃”。

亚马逊并不是唯一一家在 2023 年缩减规模的大型在线零售商。Wayfair 在 1 月底表示，将裁员 1,750 名团队成员，占其全球员工总数的 10%。其中约 1,200 名员工被裁减，目的是“消除管理层”，并以其他方式帮助公司变得更精简、更灵活。 Wayfair 自 2022 年 8 月以来一直在削减成本（包括 870 个职位），但认为裁员有助于其比预期更早实现盈亏平衡。

Another Meta whistleblower has testified before Congress regarding safety issues on the company's platforms. On the same day that Frances Haugen told Congress in 2021 how Meta could fix some of its safety problems , Arturo Béjar, a former director of engineering for Protect and Care at Facebook, sent CEO Mark Zuckerberg and other executives an email regarding the harms that young people may face while using the company's products.

Two years later, Béjar was the sole witness in a Senate Judiciary subcommittee hearing titled "Social Media and the Teen Mental Health Crisis." In his testimony, Béjar claimed he was subpoenaed earlier this year to testify regarding emails he sent Meta higher-ups. He said he realized that since he sent them, nothing had changed at the company.

"Meta continues to publicly misrepresent the level and frequency of harm that users, especially children, experience on the platform," Béjar told the Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology and the Law in prepared remarks. "And they have yet to establish a goal for actually reducing those harms and protecting children. It's time that the public and parents understand the true level of harm posed by these 'products' and it's time that young users have the tools to report and suppress online abuse."

Béjar was an engineering director at Meta between 2009 and 2015, during which time he was responsible for protecting Facebook users. He supported a team that worked on "bullying tools for teens, suicide prevention, child safety and other difficult moments that people go through," according to his LinkedIn profile .

He testified that he initially left Meta feeling "good that we had built numerous systems that made using our products easier and safer." However, he said that, since they were 14, his daughter and her friends "repeatedly faced unwanted sexual advances, misogyny and harassment" on Instagram. According to The Wall Street Journal , which first reported on Béjar's claims, he stated that Meta's systems typically ignored reports they made or responded to say that the harassment they faced didn't break the rules.

Those issues prompted him to return to Meta in 2019, where he worked with Instagram's well-being team. "It was not a good experience. Almost all of the work that I and my colleagues had done during my earlier stint at Facebook through 2015 was gone," Béjar said in his testimony. "The tools we had built for teenagers to get support when they were getting bullied or harassed were no longer available to them. People at the company had little or no memory of the lessons we had learned earlier."

Béjar claimed that Instagram and internal research teams gathered data showing that younger teens dealt with "great distress and abuse." However, "senior management was externally reporting different data that grossly understated the frequency of harm experienced by users," he told senators.

In a 2021 email to Zuckerberg and other executives laying out some of his concerns, Béjar wrote that his then-16-year-old daughter uploaded a car-related post to Instagram only for a commenter to tell her to "get back to the kitchen." Béjar said his daughter found this upsetting. “At the same time the comment is far from being policy violating, and our tools of blocking or deleting mean that this person will go to other profiles and continue to spread misogyny," Béjar wrote. "I don't think policy/reporting or having more content review are the solutions.”

Béjar said that along with his daughter's experiences with the app, 13 percent of users aged between 13 and 15 indicated in user perception surveys that they received unwanted sexual advances on Instagram within the previous seven days. While former chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg offered sympathy toward his daughter for her negative experiences and Instagram head Adam Mosseri asked to set up a meeting, according to Béjar, Zuckerberg never responded to the email.

"That was unusual," Béjar said in his testimony. "It might have happened, but I don't recall Mark ever not responding to me previously in numerous communications, either by email or by asking for an in-person meeting."

Béjar told the Associated Press that Meta has to change its approach to moderating its platforms. This, according to Béjar, would require the company to place a greater onus on tackling harassment, unwanted sexual advances and other issues that don't necessarily break the company's existing rules.

He noted, for instance, that teens should be able to tell Instagram that they don't want to receive crude sexual messages, even if those don't violate the app's current policies. Béjar claims it would be easy for Meta to implement a feature through which teens could flag sexual advances that were made to them. "I believe that the reason that they're not doing this is because there's no transparency about the harms that teenagers are experiencing on Instagram," he told the BBC .

Béjar laid out several other steps that Meta could take to reduce harm users face on its platform that "do not require significant investments by the platforms in people to review content or in technical infrastructure." He added that he believes adopting such measures (which primarily focus on improving safety tools and getting more feedback from users who have experienced harm) would not severely impact the revenues of Meta or other companies that adopt them. "These reforms are not designed to punish companies, but to help teenagers," he told the subcommittee. "And over time, they will create a safer environment."

"My experience, after sending that email and seeing what happened afterwards, is that they knew, there were things they could do about it, they chose not to do them and we cannot trust them with our children," Béjar said during the hearing. "It's time for Congress to act. The evidence, I believe, is overwhelming."

“Every day countless people inside and outside of Meta are working on how to help keep young people safe online," a Meta spokesperson told Engadget in a statement. "The issues raised here regarding user perception surveys highlight one part of this effort, and surveys like these have led us to create features like anonymous notifications of potentially hurtful content and comment warnings.我们还与家长和专家合作推出了 30 多种工具来支持青少年及其家人获得安全、积极的在线体验。所有这些工作仍在继续。”

Béjar hopes his testimony will help spur Congress to “pass the legislation that they've been working on” regarding the online safety of younger users. Two years ago, Haugen disclosed internal Facebook research indicating that Instagram was "harmful for a sizable percentage of teens." Growing scrutiny led Meta to halt work on a version of Instagram for kids.

Since Haugen's testimony, Congress has made some efforts to tackle online safety issues for kids, but those have stuttered. The Kids Online Safety Act (KOSA) twice advanced from a Senate committee ( in the previous Congress and earlier this year ), but it hasn't reached a floor vote and there's no companion bill in the House. Among other things, the bill seeks to give kids aged under 16 the ability to switch off "addictive features and algorithm-based recommendations, as well as having more protections for their data. Similar bills have stalled in Congress.

Last month, attorneys general from 41 states and the District of Columbia sued Meta over alleged harms it caused to young users. “Meta designed and deployed harmful and psychologically manipulative product features to induce young users' compulsive and extended Platform use, while falsely assuring the public that its features were safe and suitable for young users," according to the lawsuit. Béjar said he consulted with the attorneys general and provided them with documents to help their case.

"I'm very hopeful that your testimony, added to the lawsuit that's been brought by state attorneys general across the country ... added to the interest that I think is evidenced by the turnout of our subcommitee today, will enable us to get the Kids Online Safety Act across the finish line," subcommittee chair Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) told Béjar. Blumenthal, one of KOSA's original sponsors, expressed hope that other legislation "that can finally break the straitjacket that Big Tech has imposed on us" will be enacted into law.

Over the last few years and amid the rise of TikTok, Meta has once again been focusing on bringing younger users into its ecosystem, with Zuckerberg stating in 2021 (just a couple of weeks after Haugen's testimony) that the company would refocus its “teams to make serving young adults their North Star rather than optimizing for the larger number of older people.” Recently, the company lowered the minimum age for using its Meta Quest VR headsets to 10 through the use of parent-controlled accounts.

Factors to consider when buying a MacBook

Compared to PCs, Apple computers tend to have more streamlined specifications. The company has long been known for this simplicity, and the M-series “system-on-a-chip” condenses things even further. The M1, M2 and M3 chips combine, among other technologies, the CPU, graphics card and unified memory (RAM). Apple's Neural Engine is included too, which is a specialized group of processor cores that handles machine learning tasks such as image analysis and voice recognition. While a unified chip means you have fewer decisions to make when picking a MacBook, there are still a few factors to consider, including the number of CPU cores, amount of RAM, storage capacity, screen size, and, obviously, price.

CPU cores

The M1 chip is offered with a single configuration: an 8-core CPU and a 7-core GPU. At the other end of the spectrum, the M3 Max chip is built with up to a 16-core CPU and a 40-core GPU. Cores are, in essence, smaller processing units that can handle different tasks simultaneously. Having more of them translates to the computer being able to run multiple programs and applications at once, while also smoothly processing demanding tasks like video editing and high-level gaming. In short, more cores allow for more advanced computing. But if your needs fall below professional-level gaming and cinematic video and audio editing, getting the highest number of cores is likely overkill — and after all, more cores equals higher cost and more power usage.

RAM

Your options for memory, RAM or, in Apple's terminology, Unified memory, varies depending on the chip you choose. The MacBook Air with the M1 chip comes with either 8 or 16GB of RAM. With the M3 chip, you can opt for 8, 16 or 24GB. The M3 Pro chip includes 18 or 36GB of memory, while the most powerful M3 Max chip gives you the option of 48, 64, or, in a first for an Apple laptop, a whopping 128GB.

You've likely heard the analogy comparing memory to the amount of workspace available on a literal desktop surface, whereas storage is the amount of drawers you have to store projects to work on later. The larger the worktop surface, the more projects you can work on at once. The bigger the drawers, the more you can save for later.

More RAM is ideal for people who plan to work in multiple programs at once. And the more demanding each program is, the more RAM will be required. Extra memory can also come in handy if you're the type who likes to have infinite numbers of tabs open on your browser. If your daily workflow doesn't involve simultaneously using a vast number of memory-intensive programs, you can save yourself money and buy the RAM configuration that you're most likely to actually use.

For casual users, 8GB may be enough, however, if you can afford an upgrade to 16GB of RAM, we recommend going doing so, as modern browsers tend to be pretty memory-hungry. Investing in more RAM now will give your new MacBook a longer lifespan of reliable use. It's also important to keep in mind that, unlike most PCs, the RAM in current-model MacBooks is not user-upgradable, so you'll want to get what you plan on needing at the outset.

Storage capacity (SSD)

Storage options range from 256GB of SSD for the M1 MacBook Air and 8TB of storage for the MacBook Pros with the M3 Max chip. If you want to rotate between a long roster of game titles or keep lots of high-res videos on hand, you'll want more storage. If you're mostly working with browser- and cloud-based applications, you can get away with a smaller-capacity configuration. That said, we recommend springing for 512GB of storage or more, if it's within your budget. You'll quickly feel the limits of a 256GB machine as it ages since the operating system alone takes up a good portion of that space. Having 1TB will feel even roomier and allow for more data storage over the life of your laptop.

When Apple announced the iPhone 15 , the company also announced new iCloud+ storage storage plans , with subscriptions that allow up to 12TB of storage. You could also transfer files to an external storage device. But if you don't want to pay for a monthly subscription and prefer the convenience of having immediate access to your files, it's best to get the highest amount of storage space your budget allows for at the outset.

Screen size

MacBooks come in 13-, 14-, 15- and 16-inch sizes. That might not seem like a huge difference, but, as Engadget's Nathan Ingraham noted when he reviewed the new 15-inch MacBook Air, “a bigger screen makes a surprising difference.” That's especially true if you plan to use your laptop as an all-day productivity machine and won't be using an external monitor. More space means you can more clearly view side-by-side windows and have a more immersive experience when watching shows or gaming.

But screen size is the main factor influencing weight. The 13-inch MacBook Air M2 weighs 2.7 pounds, whereas the top-end 16-inch MacBook Pro weighs 4.8 pounds. If you plan to travel a lot or swap your work locations regularly, a smaller screen will make life easier in the long run.

All MacBooks feature IPS LCD panels ( in-plane switching , liquid crystal display), which Apple markets as Retina displays. The MacBook Air M1 has a Retina display. A Liquid Retina display comes with the M2 MacBook Air and the Liquid Retina XDR display comes with the 14- and 16-inch MacBook Pros. “Liquid” refers to the way the lighted portion of the display “flows” within the contours of the screen, filling the rounded corners and curving around the camera notch. “XDR” is what Apple calls HDR (high dynamic range).

Compared to most other laptops, MacBook displays are notably bright, sharp and lush. But one feature worth pointing out is another Apple marketing term: ProMotion. It's the company's term to describe a screen with a higher, 120Hz refresh rate, which results in smoother scrolling and more fluid-looking graphics. Only the 14- and 16-inch MacBook Pros offer ProMotion; the other models max out at 60Hz, which is perfectly fine for everyday browsing and typical workdays. But if you want buttery-smooth motion from your display, you'll have to shell out more money for an upgraded model.

Price

The least expensive MacBook is the 13-inch M1 Air with 8GB of RAM and 256GB of SSD, which sells for $999 and has been regularly going for $750 at multiple retailers. Alternatively, you can spend up to $7,199 for the 16-inch MacBook Pro M3 Max with 128GB of RAM and 8TB of storage. Chip type, screen size, memory and storage capacity all influence the price at checkout, which is why guides like this may help you determine just what you need (and what you don't) so you can get the most cost-effective machine for you.

Our guide suggests MacBook Air M2 for most people, the MacBook Air M1 for students and those on a budget, and the 14- or 16-inch MacBook Pros for professionals. If you have extra money to spare once you've picked your machine, we recommend upgrading to at least 16GB of RAM and 512GB of storage to make your machine as future-proof as possible.

Best MacBook overall: MacBook Air M2

Our resident laptop expert Devindra Hardawar called the MacBook Air M2 a “near-perfect Mac” in his review , awarding it a high score of 96. It's the newer of the two Air models Apple still sells, and notably a better buy than the 13-inch MacBook Pro, as the latter is both heavier and more expensive. The Air was built around the new M2 chip and completely refreshed for 2022 with a new, squared-off design thatditches the wedge shape.

It's a fanless system which means it's quiet, but to keep things cool, the CPU does have to be throttled occasionally.

Overall, it's an excellent choice for everyday use and can handle most tasks. Of course, if you're planning on doing intensive video editing, you'll likely want something more powerful, such as the MacBook Pro M2 , but the Air is arguably the best multipurpose, ultraportable laptop that Apple makes.

Our review MacBook Air had an M2 chip with a 10-core GPU, along with 16GB of memory and 1TB of storage. That configuration will run you $1,799 . Instead, we recommend the $1,499 setup with an 8-core GPU, 16GB of memory and 512GB of SSD storage .

Best budget MacBook: MacBook Air M1

The MacBook Air M1 may not have the most current Apple silicon, but it gets so much right that it's still an excellent laptop, and probably the best MacBook for college students. For multimedia professionals, we recommend bumping up to the M3 Pro chip with an 11-core CPU and 14-core GPU. You can grab one with a 14-inch screen, 18GB of memory and 512GB of SSD for $1,999. Sony has just unveiled its latest pro-oriented mirrorless camera, and we now know why it took them four years to develop it The Alpha A9 III is the first full-frame camera on the market with a global stacked sensor, a sort of holy grail in the photographic world. It allows for some wild specs, like 120fps shooting speeds with no blackout, up to a 1/80,000th of a second shutter speed and zero rolling shutter — albeit with a 24.6 megapixel resolution that may disappoint some.

The new tech opens up a lot of new possibilities for photographers. Without the constraints of a physical shutter (no, there isn't one), it can shoot full-resolution, blackout-free 14-bit RAW bursts at up to 120fps with a 1.6 second buffer (around 180 shots). Sony also installed the latest Bionz XR image processor and "high-density focal plane phase detection AF" that allows for real-time autofocus (AF) tracking.

"A designated AI processing unit uses real-time recognition AF to recognize a wide variety of subjects with high precision," Sony explains in the press release. "By combining high-speed performance of up to 120 fps with highly accurate subject recognition performance, it is possible to easily photograph scenes and moments that cannot be seen with the naked eye."

The global shutter also allows for shutter speeds of 1/80,000th of a second (1/16,000th during continuous shooting), ten times faster than most cameras. Compatible flashes can be synced all the way up to the maximum shutter speed, rather than being limited to much lower speeds in electronic shutter mode — normally around 1/250th to 1/500th of a second. It also allows the shutter speed to be finely adjusted to eliminate flicker in video. And Sony is offering a 1-second pre-burst feature that can capture scenes before the shutter button is pressed, reducing the possibility of a missed shot.

The stacked global shutter provides large benefits for video, as well. It's Sony's first camera to support 4K 120p video with no cropping and does so with no rolling shutter distortion (skewing), along with 4K 60p with 6K oversampling. It also offers 10-bit recording with S-Log3 capture in all video modes (including 4K 120p), along with S-Cinetone borrowed from the company's high-end Venice lineup that "makes human skin tones and subjects stand out beautifully," Sony said. It should be one of Sony's best-focusing cameras for video, as all the photo subject tracking features work in that mode, too.

It's got a long list of other features you'd expect on a high-end Sony camera, most notably in-body stabilization with up to 8 stops of shake reduction. The electronic viewfinder is Sony's best with 9.44 million dots, and It resolves the rear display tilt vs. flip debate by doing both of those things. And to help clear the buffer as quickly as possible, the A9 III supports fast CFexpress Type A cards on top of SD UHS II, much like the Alpha A1.

Other specs show an ISO range of 250-25600 (expandable to ISO 125–51200) with a minimum ISO that's a bit on the high side. That shouldn't bother photographers on sunny days, given the extremely fast shutter speeds, but video shooters will need ND filters to block some light.

What will be a key for this camera is the image quality and low-light sensitivity, given that this is an all-new sensor and there's not a lot of data on global shutters. Sony didn't release any sample photos yet from what I've seen, so upcoming reviews of this model will be key. The Alpha A9 III goes on pre-order tomorrow for $6,000, with a vertical grip available for $400 — but won't arrive until next spring.

GM's autonomous vehicle Cruise division is already going through a rough patch, with the California Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) recently suspending its driverless permits over safety issues. Now, several new reports have highlighted other issues with the company, including problems with its autonomous vehicles (AVs) recognizing children and the frequency with which human operators must remotely take control. The company also just announced that it's temporarily suspending production of its fully autonomous Origin transport.

The most concerning issue is that Cruise reportedly kept its vehicles on the streets even though it knew they had problems recognizing children, The Intercept reported. According to internal, previously unreported safety assessment materials, Cruises autonomous vehicles may have been unable to effectively detect children in order to take extra precautions.

"Cruise AVs may not exercise additional care around children," the document states. Because of that, the company was concerned that its robotaxis might drive too fast near children who could move unexpectedly into the street. Cruise also lacks data around child-specific situations, like kids separating from adults, falling, riding bicycles or wearing costumes.

In one simulation, the company couldn't rule out a scenario where a vehicle strikes a child. In another specific test drive, a vehicle detected a child-sized dummy but still struck it with a mirror at 28 MPH. The company chalked up the problems to a inadequate software and testing — specifically, it lacks AI software that could automatically detect child-shaped objects around the car and maneuver accordingly.

In a statement to The Intercept , Cruise admitted that its vehicles sometimes temporarily lost track of children by the side of the road during simulation testing. It added that the problem was fixed and only seen in testing and not on public streets, though it didn't say what specific actions it took to resolve the issue. A spokesperson also said that the system hadn't failed to detect the children, but did fail to classify them as such.

It further stated that the odds of an accident involving children were relatively low. "We determined from observed performance on-road, the risk of the potential collision with a child could occur once every 300 million miles at fleet driving, which we have since improved upon. There have been no on-road collisions with children."

The report also notes that Cruise AVs have trouble detecting large holes in the road, such as construction site pits with crews inside, something the company itself called a "major risk." GM's own documents indicated that even with its small AV fleet, a vehicle was likely to drive into such a hole at least once a year — and into a pit with people inside once every four years.

That scenario almost happened, according to video reviewed by The Intercept . Onboard cameras show an AV driving right to the edge of a pit, inches away from workers, despite the presence of construction cones. It only stopped because someone waved a "slow" sign in front of the windshield.

"Enhancing our AV's ability to detect potential hazards around construction zones has been an area of focus, and over the last several years we have conducted extensive human-supervised testing and simulations resulting in continued improvements," the company said in a statement. "These include enhanced cone detection, full avoidance of construction zones with digging or other complex operations, and immediate enablement of the AV's Remote Assistance support/supervision by human observers."

All of that raises the question of whether Cruise should be operating its vehicles on public roads. "If you can't see kids, it's very hard for you to accept that not being high risk — no matter how infrequent you think it's going to happen," Carnegie Mellon engineering professor Phil Koopman told The Intercept .

The child detection issue isn't the only recent exposé on Cruise, as it turns out that the robotaxis aren't really autonomous at all. In fact, they require human assistance every four to five miles, according to a report in The New York Times   confirmed in large part by Cruise CEO Kyle Vogt in Hacker News .

"Cruise AVs are being remotely assisted (RA) 2-4 percent of the time on average, in complex urban environments." wrote Vogt. That equates to someone intervening every four to five miles, which could be multiple times on many trips. There is typically one remote assistant "for every 15-20 driverless AVs," Cruise stated later.

In a statement to CNBC , the company provided additional details: "Often times the AV proactively initiates these [remote assistance actions] before it is certain it will need help such as when the AV's intended path is obstructed (eg construction blockages or detours) or if it needs help identifying an object," a spokesperson wrote. "Remote assistance is in session about 2-4 percent of the time the AV is on the road, which is minimal, and in those cases the RA advisor is providing wayfinding intel to the AV, not controlling it remotely."

Finally, it appears that Cruise has halted production of its Origin autonomous vehicle after the California DMV pulled its license, Forbes reported. In an all-hands meeting with employees, Vogt, referring to the DMV license withdrawal, stated that "because a lot of this is in flux, we did make the decision with GM to pause production of the Origin," according to audio from the meeting. A GM spokesperson later confirmed to Engadget that "We are finishing production on a small number of pre-commercial vehicles and after that, plan to temporarily pause production."

Cruise is still operating its AVs in California, but now must have a human backup driver at the wheel. Meanwhile, California says it has given Cruise a path back to driverless operation “The DMV has provided Cruise with the steps needed to apply to reinstate its suspended permits, which the DMV will not approve until the company has fulfilled the requirements to the department's satisfaction,” it said in a statement.
